message.raw:
* Implement feature of saving an array of images when expose() called multiple
times with identical name and frame type.
* Set default frame_type='frame'.
* Add mock camera class, for testing without an actual camera present.
* Fix bug in continuous acquisition
* Fix bug whereby images were not correctly matched to frames in the case of
  labscript expose() functions being called out-of-order with respect to the
  time of each frame.
*
message.html:
• Implement feature of saving an array of images when expose() called multiple
    times with identical name and frame type.
  • Set default frame_type='frame'.
  • Add mock camera class, for testing without an actual camera present.
  • Fix bug in continuous acquisition
  • Fix bug whereby images were not correctly matched to frames in the case of
    labscript expose() functions being called out-of-order with respect to the
    time of each frame.
    *

summary.raw:
* Implement feature of saving an array of images when expose() called multiple
times with identical name and frame type.
* Set default frame_type='frame'.
* Add mock camera class, for testing without an actual camera present.
* Fix bug in continuous acquisition
* Fix bug whereby images were not correctly matched to frames in the case of
  labscript expose() functions being called out-of-order with respect to the
  time of each frame.
*
summary.html:
• Implement feature of saving an array of images when expose() called multiple
    times with identical name and frame type.
  • Set default frame_type='frame'.
  • Add mock camera class, for testing without an actual camera present.
  • Fix bug in continuous acquisition
  • Fix bug whereby images were not correctly matched to frames in the case of
    labscript expose() functions being called out-of-order with respect to the
    time of each frame.
    *

values.message:
* Implement feature of saving an array of images when expose() called multiple
times with identical name and frame type.
* Set default frame_type='frame'.
* Add mock camera class, for testing without an actual camera present.
* Fix bug in continuous acquisition
* Fix bug whereby images were not correctly matched to frames in the case of
  labscript expose() functions being called out-of-order with respect to the
  time of each frame.
*

Have IMAQdxCamera use the hostname of the parent process to determine
the zmq connection for sending images.

message.raw:
Use a dedicated zmq socket for sending image data from worker to parent
rather than using state machine work requests for every frame. Otherwise the GUI
flickers with state changes for every frame, more CPU is consumed per frame,
and the data is serialised using pickle, which is less efficient that using
numpy buffers. This all wastes CPU, limits frame rate, and looks ugly.

This requires some care since the receiving thread must be cleaned up when the
tab restarts. Therefore the tab restart() method is overridden to shutdown the
corresponding ZMQserver.
message.html:
Use a dedicated zmq socket for sending image data from worker to parent
rather than using state machine work requests for every frame. Otherwise the GUI
flickers with state changes for every frame, more CPU is consumed per frame,
and the data is serialised using pickle, which is less efficient that using
numpy buffers. This all wastes CPU, limits frame rate, and looks ugly.

This requires some care since the receiving thread must be cleaned up when the
tab restarts. Therefore the tab restart() method is overridden to shutdown the
corresponding ZMQserver.

summary.raw:
Use a dedicated zmq socket for sending image data from worker to parent
rather than using state machine work requests for every frame. Otherwise the GUI
flickers with state changes for every frame, more CPU is consumed per frame,
and the data is serialised using pickle, which is less efficient that using

This requires some care since the receiving thread must be cleaned up when the
tab restarts. Therefore the tab restart() method is overridden to shutdown the

summary.html:
Use a dedicated zmq socket for sending image data from worker to parent
rather than using state machine work requests for every frame. Otherwise the GUI
flickers with state changes for every frame, more CPU is consumed per frame,
and the data is serialised using pickle, which is less efficient that using
numpy buffers. This all wastes CPU, limits frame rate, and looks ugly.

This requires some care since the receiving thread must be cleaned up when the
tab restarts. Therefore the tab restart() method is overridden to shutdown the
corresponding ZMQserver.

values.message:
Use a dedicated zmq socket for sending image data from worker to parent
rather than using state machine work requests for every frame. Otherwise the GUI
flickers with state changes for every frame, more CPU is consumed per frame,
and the data is serialised using pickle, which is less efficient that using
numpy buffers. This all wastes CPU, limits frame rate, and looks ugly.

This requires some care since the receiving thread must be cleaned up when the
tab restarts. Therefore the tab restart() method is overridden to shutdown the
corresponding ZMQserver.

message.raw:
Working on converting the IMAQdx implementation into a regular labscript driver.

With the in-progress remote devices functionality, there is no longer any reason
for the camera to have a separate 'server' just because it is connected to
a different computer.
message.html:
Working on converting the IMAQdx implementation into a regular labscript driver.

With the in-progress remote devices functionality, there is no longer any reason
for the camera to have a separate 'server' just because it is connected to
a different computer.

it is nonzero. This avoids potentially dividing by zero when the array is
zero everywhere.

message.raw:
Modify LightCrafter to round up to a multiple of four images that it sends
to the DMD - even though they do not have triggers.

For the model we have, it is a requirement when the number of images is > 24
that there must be a multiple of 2 images, and when > 48, a multiple of four.
We just round up to a multiple of four always.

For the model we have, it is a requirement when the number of images is > 24
that there must be a multiple of 2 images, and when > 48, a multiple of four.
We just round up to a multiple of four always.

message.raw:
Ignore ports with no lines in manual mode.

This prevents a crash due to the NI_PCI_6534 having zero lines on port 4.
We could have had the introspection code ingore ports with no lines, but then
the port numbers would not be contiguous, since this device has a port 5.
Easier for now to keep the assumption of contiguous port numbers and simply not
use the ports with no lines. But we may revisit this if there are further
issues with this phantom port 4.

message.raw:
Use a multiple-of-four number of samples per chan to test digital ports, as some
models (observed with PCI 6534) require this.

Use a whole digital port instead of just one line, as some
models (also PCI 6534) require this. Catch errors about requiring multiple ports
at a time for 653x models, and return True since these models do support
buffered output despite these other requirements.

The devices that require the number of samples per channel to be a multiple of
four may be a problem in labscript, since labscript does not know or care about
such requirements presently.

such requirements presently.

models (also PCI 6534) require this. Catch errors about requiring multiple ports
at a time for 653x models, and return True since these models do support
buffered output despite these other requirements.

The devices that require the number of samples per channel to be a multiple of

message.raw:
Use David Meyer's technique of iterating over all baud rates at startup if
communication cannot be established at the current baud rate.

This resolves an issue whereby restarting a tab in BLACS does not cleanly shut
it down, and so the Novatech's baud rate would not be reset to te default value
upon restart. The startup code would then not be able to communicate with it.

BLACS should try to cleanly shut down tabs upon restart, if possible, but
that is a separate issue.

upon restart. The startup code would then not be able to communicate with it.

BLACS should try to cleanly shut down tabs upon restart, if possible, but
that is a separate issue.

message.raw:
Rename submodules of dummy pseudoclock to all be plural.
This is a better precedent for devices to use, as all submodules can follow
the same naming convention and not have to rename from singular to plural
if they grow an extra class.

message.raw:
Updates after testing in the lab (made all labscript and BLACS parameters correctly reference clock frequency)

* Added the automatic creation of a `WaitMonitor` so that you don't have to remember the syntax (since it's a bit meaningless for this device)
* Added a configurable trigger debouce parameter
* Waits (and inbuilt wait monitor) have been tested and work. The measured wait duration appears reasonably accurate, but it's hard to tell without a function generator that is referenced to a common 10MHz signal and is capable of producing a delayed pulse and ensuring that we account correctly for output delays in NI cards, etc. etc). I have no reason to doubt it's accuracy though as it literally just counts internal clock ticks while it waits.
* External referencing of the entire device was tested successfully (and is necessary if using it with other pseudoclocks, much like the PineBlaster). I tested with both a 33.333MHz reference and a 50MHz reference signal produced by a NB3N502 chip. The OpalKelly board stayed synchronised with our PulseBlasters that were similarly referenced to a common 10MHz GPS source.

TODO:
 * confirm it works as a secondary pseudoclock

values.message:
Updates after testing in the lab (made all labscript and BLACS parameters correctly reference clock frequency)

* Added the automatic creation of a `WaitMonitor` so that you don't have to remember the syntax (since it's a bit meaningless for this device)
* Added a configurable trigger debouce parameter
* Waits (and inbuilt wait monitor) have been tested and work. The measured wait duration appears reasonably accurate, but it's hard to tell without a function generator that is referenced to a common 10MHz signal and is capable of producing a delayed pulse and ensuring that we account correctly for output delays in NI cards, etc. etc). I have no reason to doubt it's accuracy though as it literally just counts internal clock ticks while it waits.
* External referencing of the entire device was tested successfully (and is necessary if using it with other pseudoclocks, much like the PineBlaster). I tested with both a 33.333MHz reference and a 50MHz reference signal produced by a NB3N502 chip. The OpalKelly board stayed synchronised with our PulseBlasters that were similarly referenced to a common 10MHz GPS source.

 * confirm it works as a secondary pseudoclock

message.raw:
Fixed a few bugs on Python 2.7 with unicode literals imported, and updated a few constants.

Still need to do the following tests:
 * test on a real apparatus
 * confirm that the trigger/wait delays are correct
 * check runviewer
 * confirm length of measured waits is accurate
 * check external clocking option (need to find a 100MHz square wave for this though I think)
 * enforce a minimum time between waits

message.raw:
Added tentative support for the Cicero pseudoclock that uses an Opal Kelly XEM3001 FPGA development board.

Firmware for the FPGA is available from #!/labscript_suite/opalkellyxem3001/

message.raw:
Work around the "digital outputs all being zero crashes DAQmx" issue differently
by running DO as static if DOs are all zero. This removes the requirement to
have dummy DO just to avoid this issue, including in connecition tables where
usually there are no user-given instructions.

The downside to this is the beginning of output will not be in-time with the
pseudoclock, instead it will be in software time beforehand.
Some other devices are implemented this way too though, so perhaps we are not
making any guarantees about this in any case.
